Performance Indicators and Analysis 

 
A. 
 
2. 
According to the Constitution of Uzbekistan, all citizens are entitled to basic education. 
Provided by the public sector, basic education starts at age 6/7 and comprises grades 1–9 with 
an  additional  2  years  of  high  school  in  grades  10  and  11.  This  11-year  system  is  due  to  be 
phased out by 2010 when it will be replaced by a 12-year system, which will be compulsory. The 
12-year  system  will  provide  3  years  of  senior  secondary  education  after  grade  9  either  in 
academic  lyceums  or  in  technically  and  vocationally  oriented  professional  colleges.  The 
restructuring of basic and senior secondary education has been a focus of sector reforms since 
1997. Higher education consists of a 4-year first degree program followed by a 2-year masters 
program and then a doctoral program. Information on the basic education system is in Appendix 
2.  
 
3. 
In  2003/04  about  6.1  million  students  were  enrolled  in  basic  education.  With  a  net 
enrolment  rate  estimated  at  over  98%  and  no  significant  gender  differentials  in  primary 
education,  Uzbekistan  scores  high  on  the  two  Millennium  Development  Goals  relevant  to 
education.  However,  the  level  of  attendance  is  reported  to  be  a  problem  especially  in  poor 
regions, although reliable data is not available. The primary completion rate is estimated to be 
close to 100%. Over the next 5 years basic education enrolment is expected to decrease due to 
(i)  the  transfer  of  approximately  600,000  grade  10  and  11  students  to  senior  secondary 
education  as  the  system  moves  to  a  12-year  system;  and  (ii)  a  decline  in  new  enrolments  in 
grade 1 of approximately 10,000–20,000 students per year resulting from falling birth rates and 
an  aging  population.  Enrolments  are  expected  to  stabilize  in  2010  at  around  5.3  million  in 
grades  1–9.  In  2004,  20.7%  of  the  9,757  general  secondary  schools  were  located  in  urban 
areas. Approximately 40% of basic education enrolments are in grades 1–4.  
 
4. 
Public  expenditure  for  education  as  a  high  priority  sector  has  increased  in  real  terms 
every year since 2000, and stood at 9.5% of gross domestic product in 2005. The share of basic 
education  in  total  education  expenditure  has  gone  up  from  45.5%  to  50.3%  over  the  past  5 
years,  and  is  expected  to  rise  further.  Since  2004  the  Government  has  accelerated  efforts  to 
refocus  on  basic  education  and  to  remedy  many  years  of  underfunding  of  the  subsector.  The 
National Program for Basic Education Development 2004–2009 was launched in 2004 with the 
key objective to urgently rehabilitate and upgrade the basic education system especially in rural 
areas,  including  physical  plants,  learning  and  teaching  materials,  computers,  laboratory  and 
sports equipment, and curriculum reform.

Integrating  ICT  in  basic  education  is  an  integral  part  of  the  Government’s  long-term 
strategic  objective  of  transforming  the  education  system  into  one  consistent  with  a  market-
based  economy  in  the  21st  century.  While  ICT  promises  substantial  potential  gains,  a 
discussion of a number of key challenges follows.  
 

1. 

Benefits of ICT Development in Basic Education   

 
7. 
To meet the needs of the 21st century, which is increasingly knowledge and information 
based,  basic  education  must  produce  graduates  who  can  learn  quickly  and  independently  to 
ensure  that  the  future  workforce  is  sufficiently  flexible  to  be  able  to  apply  old  skills  in  new 
situations,  and  to  acquire  new  skills  and  knowledge  quickly  when  needed.  Integrating  ICT  in 
schools will help to achieve this fundamental educational objective in the following five areas.  
  
Ensuring Computer Competence as an Essential Basic Skill. ICT capability involves 
8. 
technical  and  cognitive  proficiency  to  access,  use,  develop,  create,  and  communicate 
information  appropriately  using  ICT  tools.  Improved  computer  skills  with  basic  ICT  tools  (word 
processing,  spreadsheets,  databases,  presentation  software,  and  other  applications)  increase 
student  productivity;  ICT  skills  are  becoming  a  universal  basic  requirement.  Currently,  such 
skills  are  not  learned  in schools,  as more  than  half  of  students  have  no  excess  to computers, 
and for those who do, computers are used only for theoretical informatics.  
 
Promoting  Student-Centered  Learning  to  Improve  Learner  Engagement  and 
9. 
Motivation. ICT will support the change to student-centered learning, which is at the center of 
ongoing  reforms  in  basic  education.  Despite  years  of  efforts,  didactic  teaching  methodologies 
and  teacher-directed  classrooms  still  dominate.  A  key  advantage  of  ICT  is  to  give  students—
traditionally  on  the  passive  receiving  end—access  to  an  effective  means  of  acquiring, 
processing,  and  applying  knowledge  and  information.  Students  enjoy  using  ICT  because  it 
provides  alternative  and  user-friendly  approaches  to  learning  and  the  chance  to  develop  the 
skills  needed  for  the  future.  ICT  facilitates  students  learning  in  groups,  working  with  other 
learners,  being  creative,  learning  through  challenging  game-like  activities,  and  setting  clear 
personal  learning  goals.  ICT  use  also  stimulates  increased  teacher-student  interaction.  As 
students  develop  skills,  they  become  more  engaged  with  their  own  learning  and  thus  more 
motivated. With ICT the curriculum can be tailored to a student’s individual learning needs and 
can be readily adapted to meet the needs of students with learning or physical disabilities.  
 
10. 
Developing  Higher  Order  Thinking  Skills  and  Independent  Learning  Skills.  ICT 
helps students to discriminate in their use of information and ICT tools, and to be appreciative

13.  While integrating ICT in learning and teaching promises substantial potential benefits, to

Teachers and ICT Use. Experience shows that teachers are a key to the success of ICT 
use  in  schools.  To  date,  a  large  majority  of  general  secondary  teachers  in  Uzbekistan  have 
never  used  a  computer  for  any  purpose.  This  is  partly  because  of  the  policy  of  computer  use 
only for the  subject of informatics, and partly due to the lack of computers in schools. To turn 
teachers  into  champions  of  ICT  use  and  a  prime  source  of  support  for  students,  they

Financial Sustainability of ICT. ICT in basic education is costly. At current unit costs, 
with  network-ready  desktop  personal  computers5  and  a  target  computer-student  ratio  of  1:42, 
equipping every basic education school will cost around $116 million. The annual replacement 
costs of this investment are around $23 million at current costs based on a 5-year replacement 
cycle.  Operational  costs  (consumables,  maintenance,  and  servicing)  would  add  an  estimated 
$10  million  a  year.  Even  without  internet  connectivity,  the  recurrent  costs  could  amount  to 
around  $35  million  per  year,  which  is  equivalent  to  6.2%  of  the  basic  education  budget.  In 
addition  to  these  direct  recurrent  costs,  indirect  recurrent  costs  include  training  teachers, 
developing  learning  materials,  providing  technical  and  managerial  support,  and  undertaking 
monitoring and evaluation (M&E) of progress. The total cost of ownership of integrating ICT in 
schools,  even  at  the  current  planned  moderate  level,  will  be  substantial.  In  addition,  under 
current  financing  arrangements,  schools  have  insufficient  operation  and  maintenance  (O&M) 
budgets. The requirement from ICT use would add substantially to this gap, which, unless fully 
provided by the Government, would seriously impair ICT development in schools.  
 
20.

development  in  schools,  with  the  objective  of  reducing  and  bridging  the  internal  digital  divide. 
Already  funding  to  schools  varies  significantly  by  oblast.  Many  schools  rely  on  parental 
contributions  to  make  up  for  shortfalls  in  O&M  budgets.  This  represents  a  disproportionate 
burden  on  the  poor.  In  general,  schools  in  relatively  affluent  urban  areas  tend  to  have  better 
teachers  and  conditions,  and  are  better  positioned  to  generate  income  to  support  ICT.  These 
factors combined pose a serious challenge for the Government to provide the same access to 
schools in poor, rural, and remote areas as in urban areas and affluent centers.

Government Strategy and Policy  

  
21. 
Integrating ICT in schools is a key strategy of the Government to achieve its subsector 
objective of improving the quality and relevance of basic education, and to ensure equal access 
to all. Full integration of ICT in basic education will require an ICT-based curriculum, abundant 
learning  materials,  a  majority  of  teachers  adept  at  ICT  use,  adequate  school  conditions  and 
physical  infrastructure  in  place,  provision  of  financial  resources  to  cover  the  total  cost  of  ICT 
ownership, and specifically designed pro-poor interventions from the public sector. At present, 
Uzbekistan  has  embarked  on  the  initial  phase  to  providing  full  ICT  integration  in  schools. 
Cognizant of the tasks and the need to overcome considerable constraints, the Government has 
developed a draft strategy with ADB assistance to guide medium- and long-term implementation 
of its ICT in basic education program (Supplementary Appendix A).  
 
22. 
The draft strategy focuses on long-term ICT development in basic education that will be 
financially  sustainable,  educationally  effective,  and  pro-poor.  To  achieve  this,  the  strategy 
proposes a phased approach, with the first phase in 2006–2010 and the second in 2011–2015. 
This  approach  prioritizes  the  limited  resources  available  during  the  first  phase  to  build  a  firm 
foundation  for  the  long-term  integration  of  ICT  in  basic  education.  Key  to  the  first  phase  is  to 
demonstrate real education benefits from ICT use in all schools. This, along with improvements 
in the broad financial and fiscal environments, will lay the foundation for larger scale and more 
integrated use of ICT in the second phase.  
 
23. 
Central  to  successful  implementation  during  the  first  phase  is  the  establishment  of 
school  clusters.  Each  cluster  will  contain  an  average  of  11  schools  so  that  860  clusters  will 
cover all schools in Uzbekistan. Each cluster will have a CLS whose role will be to lead all other 
schools in the cluster in activities relating to integrating ICT in teaching and learning. The school 
cluster  concept  is  strategic—instead  of  spreading  the  limited  financial  and  human  resources 
evenly but thinly across all schools, the country will focus its resources on (i) establishing CLSs 
as  champions  and  mentors  for  the use  of ICT  in  the  educational  process,  and  strongholds  for 
future  ICT  expansion;  (ii)  fostering  the  school  cluster  network  into  an  effective  decentralized 
delivery mechanism for, but not be limited to, teacher upgrading and ICT use in schools; and (iii) 
ensuring effective use of ICT in poor and remote schools including internet access.  
 
24. 
In  addition,  ICT  use  in  learning  and  teaching  will  be  restricted  to  priority  subject  areas 
over a limited number of grades during the first phase. This will give more access time to ICT 
facilities  per  student  and  teacher,  thus  allowing  real  education  benefits  to  accrue  with  limited 
financial  resources.  Further  cost  reduction  solutions  will  be  examined,  in  particular,  the  “thin 
client” option, which is promising to offer substantial savings in total cost of ownership. These 
measures combined will significantly strengthen the financial sustainability of the ICT policy.

basic  education  will  be  a  fundamental  shift  to  student  centered  learning  and  teaching 
methodologies.  This  will  be  reflected  in  (i)  the  link  between  integrated  ICT  use  in  the  school

graduates  with  the  ability  to  meet  working  life  challenges  in  the  21st  century  where  the 
workforce  will  be  required  to  have  increasingly  advanced  skills  in  information  access, 
management, processing, and usage.

1. 
The Government’s stated long-term reform goal for education is to transform the system 
into one that is consistent with a market-oriented economy and a democratic society in the 21st 
century. To realize this national aspiration, the basic education subsector faces key challenges 
to improve its quality, relevance, and equitable access for all. Major constraints are analyzed in 
this appendix (a problem tree analysis is attached).  
 
Governance and Management. Education system governance is characterized by top-
2. 
down,  overly  centralized  decision  making.  Until  recently  the  Ministry  of  Public  Education 
(MOPE)  had  no  policy  mandate  but  operated  as  the  implementing  agency  for  policies  and 
strategies determined by the Cabinet of Ministers. This situation started to change in 2005 with 
progress in decentralization and the ongoing civil service reform, which aims to provide sector 
ministries with greater policy responsibility. However, MOPE remains weak in strategic planning, 
policy  making,  and  sector  management  capacity.  Coordination  between  and  within  ministries 
and  government  agencies  especially  at  the  policy  level  is  systematically  lacking.  The 
widespread  practice  of  compartmentalization  of  responsibilities  often  leads  to  policies  and 
decision making based on insufficient information and with only a restricted understanding of the 
full implications of critical decisions.  
 
Within  this highly  bureaucratic  system,  norms  rule.  For  example,  in  all  subjects  taught, 
3. 
programs  and  standards  set  by  the  central  Government  strictly  dictate  the  contents  and  time 
allocated  for  the  subjects,  leaving  inadequate  freedom  for  schools  to  adjust  to  student  needs 
and  local  conditions.  State  norms  fix  student-teacher  ratios  countrywide,  and  schools  have 
neither  the  power  nor  budgetary  incentives  to  strive  for  optimal  use  of  existing  resources. 
Schools have little discretionary spending authority over their budgets. As a result, the system 
does not encourage nor reward capacity building in planning and management skills.  
 
Within  MOPE  many  of  these  problems  and  their  consequences  seem  to  now  be 
4. 
recognized  and  attempts  are  under  way  for  further  decentralization  of  decision  making  to 
schools and for an upgrading in school management capacity. Of particular concern is the lack 
of effective targeting of the Government’s financial support for the poorest. At present 15% of all 
textbooks (and 100% of grade 1 textbooks) are provided free of charge to schools; an annual 
fund  allocation  is  provided  to  all  schools  for  winter  clothes  and  shoes.  Unfortunately,  this  pro-
poor support is based on a fixed and equal level of support for every school, irrespective of the

rather  than  on  the  development  of  key  skills  and  competencies.  Difficulties  in  achieving

senior  educators  that  the  traditional  education model  should  not  be  significantly  changed,  and

curriculum reform that are based on minor amendments of the existing curriculum. Because little

The  overloaded  curriculum  reinforces  didactic  teacher-centered  classroom  approaches

7. 
The  current  assessment  and  testing  system  is  based  on  student  grading  by  individual 
teachers  in  the  lower  grades2  and  national  tests,  which  are  also  administered  and  marked  by 
students’  own  subject  teachers,  who  are  often  also  providing  them  with  paid  examination 
coaching.  Apart  from  potential  conflict  of  interest,  this  system  provides  for  no  effective  and 
reliable  assessment.  It  is  impossible  currently  to  compare  student  attainment  on  a  national, 
oblast, raion, or school basis, or to compare progress in the national achievement of attainment 
targets  year-on-year  or  internationally.  Current  language  of instruction  (LOI)  policy  guarantees 
the rights of ethnic minorities to education, but the policy is expensive, and concerns exist about 
inequity  in  the  educational  opportunities  and  quality  provided  to  different  language  groups. 
Equity in the provision of educational materials is a particular problem because of the relatively 
high unit costs of printing textbook titles in low print runs for small language groups. 
 
8. 
The  transition  from  an  11-  to  a  12-year  system  of  education  is  expensive  and  for  a 
number of years between 1997 and 2004 it diverted urgently needed funding away from basic 
education.  The  transition  to  a  12-year  system  where  students  will  have  to  transfer  from  basic 
schools to specialized professional colleges and academic lyceums after grade 9 will mean that 
many students will have to travel farther to school and will incur additional costs as a result. This 
could have an adverse impact on the progression rate from grade 9 to grade 10, particularly in 
rural  areas  and  for  poorer  families.  The  problem  is  aggravated  by  less  reliable  transportation 
systems in rural areas, which exacerbate the problems of student travel to more distant schools.

11. 
The  current  norm-based  budgeting  places  high  priority  on  teachers’  remuneration  and 
utility at the expense of other items. In 2005, these two items represent almost 87% of the total 
education recurrent budget. Further salary increases agreed in June 2005 might well push the 
salary/social cost component of the basic education recurrent budget over 90% in 2006. While 
increasing  teachers’  salary  is  a  good  policy  in  itself,  this  increase  without  an  increase  in  the 
general  recurrent  budget  allocation  will  bring  further  pressure  to  bear  on  already  inadequate 
school operating budgets. This may well result in increased demands for parental contributions. 
Such contributions are widely in use and have a disproportionately adverse impact on the poor.  
 
12. 
The current financing system, which establishes norms for every aspect of the education 
system; removes management flexibility from oblasts, raions, and individual schools; and makes 
developing  genuine  financial  management  skills  at  any  level  of  the  system  difficult.  The 
establishment of minimum school cost profiles and the provision of devolved, school-based, per 
capita financing budgets based on these profiles would provide the opportunity for all schools to 
take  their  own  priority  financing  decisions,  based  on  their  own  (and  their  community) 
perceptions of priority needs within an adequate budgetary framework. This could rapidly lead to 
better use of available funds and a more cost-effective school financing system,5 and relieve the 
burden on the poor.

13. 
infrastructure, equipment, and facilities. A 2004 nationwide survey revealed that 40% of schools 
are housed in inappropriate and unfit buildings. There are also wide variations in the supportive 
infrastructure, including power supplies to schools and telecommunications facilities. Resources 
tend  to  be  a  particular  problem  in  rural  areas,  where  80%  of  schools  are  located  and  where 
facilities tend to be worse. Remote schools with difficult access suffer from particular resource 
provision problems and require special consideration.

14. 
the  success  of  the  textbook  rental  scheme,  high  costs  of  textbooks  in  those  subjects  not 
covered  by  the  scheme  prevent  some  parents  from  purchasing  them.  There  is  a  clear  need 
either to reduce the number of required textbooks or to include all prescribed textbooks within 
the scheme to reduce parental expenditure on textbooks. School libraries have not been funded 
for  almost  20  years  and  school  library  stock is out-of-date and  largely redundant. This  has  an 
adverse  impact  on  the  development  of  independent  learning  and  the  shift  to  student-centered 
learning.  Laboratory  equipment  and  necessary  consumables  are  in  short  supply.  In  2004  only 
18% of basic schools had access to modern personal computers and just 50% of schools had 
access to any form of computers, including those of the Soviet era. Very few basic schools have 
internet  access  and  many  schools  cannot  afford  the  costs  of  consumables,  maintenance,  and 
servicing associated with information and communications technology (ICT) use. Almost no e-
resources are available in Uzbek or other local LOI, which limits the impact of the introduction of 
ICT. Learning materials in the local LOI are in particular short supply, which has an impact on 
equity between different LOIs.

management system; and (v) improve the existing     (INSETT) system to be closer to users, more flexible, and more

The  Project  will  have  a  direct  beneficial  impact  on  about  130,000  poor  students  in  grades  5–9  enrolled  in  the  700 
during 2006–2011.1 Specific pro-poor measures of the Project include (i) having about 70% of the 860 CLSs from poor 
schools; (ii) improved power supply to all schools,  which will ensure proper  working of the ICT facilities installed, as 
well as meet general lighting and heating needs during the winter;2 (iii) pilot testing connectivity especially for rural and 
remote areas; (iv) facilitating access to rural teachers, students, and local communities; and (v) opening ICT facilities 
in  schools  to  local  communities,  which  will  benefit  an  estimated  1  million  households.  The  Project  will  provide  ICT 
facilities and internet connections to all schools, rich and poor, urban and rural. This is pro-poor since it will help bridge 
the  internal  digital  divide.  The  Project  will  address  the  issue  of  increasing  parental  contributions,  which  burdens  the 
poor disproportionately, by ensuring that the full costs of ICT in schools are borne by the public sector with no parental 
contributions required for ICT use in schools.
